revised_title: Insect Response to Logging and Conversion to Plantation in Tropical Rain Forests
tldr: This article examines the effects of logging and conversion to plantation on insect groups in tropical rainforests. The authors studied moths and dung and carrion beetles, finding that moth diversity significantly decreases with disturbance and conversion, while beetles show less change in their faunistic composition. The study highlights the importance of conserving lowland forest habitats to protect insect species and overall tropical forest biodiversity.
